newsitem.title: USA: Fair weather forecast for U.S. shuttle.
newsitem.headline: Fair weather forecast for U.S. shuttle.

text.p: Bad weather should blow out of central Florida by Tuesday, clearing the way for the delayed launch of space shuttle Columbia, NASA said on Saturday.
Weather forecasters predicted favourable conditions for Columbia's planned 2:53 p.m. EST (1953 GMT) blastoff from NASA's Kennedy Space Centre on Florida's east coast.
"The chance of not meeting the launch weather criteria on Tuesday afternoon is just 20 percent," said NASA spokesman George Diller.
Columbia's blastoff, which had been scheduled for Friday, was delayed four days by unusually strong winds and cloudy skies that buffeted most of the state.
The countdown clocks were due to start ticking again at 1 a.m. EST (0600 GMT) on Monday, Diller said.

Columbia and its crew of five astronauts are due to spend 16 days in orbit conducting scientific research with a pair of free-flying satelites. Two spacewalks are also planned to practice construction of the international space station.
